body.p:
By last packet I wrote you
a short letter relative to our new Code of Laws, which were sent
by Mr. David hand to be transmitted to you for printing.

I am truly apprehensive, from the present dreadful
stagnation of commerce, arising from events in Europe, and the revolution
in Venezuela, which is ? our congregation of its members,
that we shall have a sound and useful Code of Laws when there
is only the shadow or skeleton of a community. You can have
no idea of the manner in which emigration from this spot has
reduced our numbers. Between the time of my first arrival here
and the present, there is a difference of from 35 to 40 regular
Sabbath attendants at public worship, grown men. Some are dead,
others gone away, and others, once in business, now in situations
which prevent them from visiting the House of God, as formerly.
It is really sad to contemplate. Add to this, the alteration in
circumstances, Even of the wealthiest, joined to the dislike of others,
from captions or other motives, to contribute to the support of the
synagogue, and you will ascertain by what a slight tenure I
hold my present appointment, and the small likelihood there is
of obtaining, in a short time, half the remuneration I now receive.

I should be really at a loss how to give my family bread, were
it not for the school; which the goodness of God has prospered to be
a provisional in these difficult times. I have so often written you
on this subject, that you must be nauseated with it; I will therefore
merely say further that religious prospects here, or rather the
upholding of a place of worship in its integrity are full of gloom
anxiety, and doubt.

New Orleans comes opportunely and makes me
offers, not in an official shape, but thro' Mr. G. Kursheedt, who
nevertheless appears to be the chosen medium of ascertaining my
sentiments. He speaks of $2000 p annum and the handsome
emoluments likely sure to result from a school. His letters thro' some
neglect, miscarried. All was report until the present month.
As I know nothing of the congregation, I have written him for
further particulars, of which I will keep you informed. There are
two things which oppose themselves, at this moment to my going.
One, the climate; the other, that independence and freedom of
action which here, as a minister I enjoy in their fullest extent.
In the internal management of the synagogue here I have no superior
to dictate to me in the capricious and often tyrannical tone of
of a Parnass. I feel myself too old to go again into leading things.
It must be with me “Aut Caesar aut nullus.” I cannot consent to
barter these privileges for gold; if they be not therefore, conceded, the
matter terminates. I have offered to serve the congregation here for

nothing, or if they will not agree to that even now, I would take
$500 a year, rather than submit, at my time of life, to restrictions
which my high spirit will not brook, in another community.
I do not think my views will suit N. O. If they do, it will be a
pleasing disappointment.

I believe I wrote you that, when last in
Jamaica, Carillon requested me to obtain the situation in N. O. for him.
I gave him a flat denial, and he is very aroth? with me in consequence.
He subsequently wrote me, that if I would give him introductory letters
and he obtained the appointment, his first duty would be to get a Hebrew.
A large concession truly! but the charmer could not charm me.
To a Congregation like that of N. O. Carillon would be a most
dangerous man. By the bye, I see the London Jewish Chronicle
has copied a paragraph from a Jamaica paper, written either by
Carillon or one of his clique, that Mendes and I have abolished
the second days holidays, that the synagogue is closed on those
days and that these alterations in our former opinions are entirely
owing to the arguments of Rabbi Carillon. On the part of Mendes
it has been denied; I did not think C of sufficient consequence
to put forth a disclaimer. My opinions of the second days are the
same as they ever were, but while persons are willing to visit the
House of God on those occasions, they will always find me sanctioning
the act. Individual synagogue amendments or even return to
primitive customs do not suit me. I want to see the whole join. I never

was and never will be Mr. Carillon's disciple. You could under
the head of news items contradict the Jamaica paragraph, and oblige
your old friend thereby.

Who is W_? I mean your correspondent in the
Occident. He writes well, and is evidently a deep thinker.
Your tactics, as regard Hebrew show your profound generalship.
The shield of Fabius and sword of marcellus have you defended
yourself with. S. M. Isaac's letter is amusing. He is much
improved.

I have no further news to communicate.
Mrs. Nathan sends her love as usual. Please remember us
both to all our old friends, and with best wishes for your
health and prosperity
